hints_html: A little algebra can get you a long way. Try simplifying the expression.
hints_latex: A little algebra can get you a long way. Try simplifying the expression.
hints_raw: A little algebra can get you a long way.  Try simplifying the expression.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
If we simply try to plug in the value x = 0, we obtain infinity minus infinity, which is undefined (you can’t say it is zero, it really depends on the “size” of each infinity in some sense). So we first do a little algebra to rewrite the two fractions as one, using a common denominator:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1}{x} = \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1-2x}{x(1-2x)} = \frac{1-(1-2x)}{x(1-2x)} = \frac{2x}{x(1-2x)}\end{aligned}\]

After canceling the x we obtain something we can compute:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0} \left( \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1}{x} \right) = \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2}{1-2x} = 2\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
If we simply try to plug in the value ''x'' = 0, we obtain infinity minus infinity, which is undefined (you can't say it is zero, it really depends on the "size" of each infinity in some sense). So we first do a little algebra to rewrite the two fractions as one, using a common denominator:
:<math>
\frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1}{x} = \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1-2x}{x(1-2x)} = \frac{1-(1-2x)}{x(1-2x)} = \frac{2x}{x(1-2x)}
</math>
After canceling the ''x'' we obtain something we can compute:
:<math>
\lim_{x \to 0} \left( \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1}{x} \right) = \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2}{1-2x} = 2
</math>
